sentence: His darling “Lotje” has sent him eggs, butter, cookies, lemonade, bread, cognac, spice cake, flowers, oranges, chocolate, books and writing paper.
Today I packed a suitcase with the stuff I’d need in case we had to flee, but as Mother correctly noted, “Where would you go?” All of Holland is being punished for the workers’ strikes.
In Dussel’s view the oranges that Kleiman so badly needs for his sick stomach will benefit his own stomach even more.
It’s absolutely disgraceful that Dussel, whom we’ve treated with such kindness and whom we took in to save from destruction, should stuff himself behind our backs and not give us anything.
At first he acted as if he didn’t want to celebrate it, but when Miep arrived with a large shopping bag overflowing with gifts, he was as excited as a little kid.
Besides that, Moms had a hard time combing her hair because the family comb has only ten teeth left.
He piled his presents on a table and displayed them for no fewer than three days, the silly old goat!
Martial law has been declared, and everyone is going to get one less butter coupon.
Tonight the guns have been banging away so much that I’ve already had to gather up my belongings four times.
We found bread, cheese, jam and eggs in his cupboard.
But what’s worse, in our opinion, is that he’s so stingy with respect to Mr. Kleiman, Mr. Voskuijl and Bep.
We have to use a very sticky liquid cleanser because there’s no more shampoo.
I washed Mother’s hair this evening, which is no easy task these days.
You mustn’t get the idea that he’s starving.
He doesn’t give them a thing.
After all, we’ve shared all we had with him!
